> Why rollbacks are painful? Aren't they work automatically? Well, I've asked AI and read about locking tables and hence other queries, additional i/o operation to revert and some more reasons . Just want to understand what is the main issue in our case

Imagine you want to import 100k rows (user data) into the database. If you use a `transaction` without chunks, if the row 99.999 fails (e.g. invalid data), the "automatic" rollback will happen... and if we are doing this in a production database, it can kill it / make it super slow (people using the platform will be affected)

That's why I asked: does it make sense to use tx here? We don't really need to rollback in this case (if a user fails to import, we can check what was the error... and reimport/fix that user only... no need to revert back the others). This is still hardcore (100k requests!)

That's why, for this particular use case... `batch` is the way to go (a single TX with all the data). You can also split into chunks, but since we only have ~1k users, no need.

Note: Transactions make sense when you want "all or nothing".... e.g. if one query fails it will leave the DB in a incoherent state

Yes, this is tricky! But it's the way to go when you have `N:N` relations.
- `1:1` (just include the data in a single  table. e.g.  builder + socialGithub => builder table)
- `1:N` (create 2 tables referencing each other from N to 1: e.g. builder + challenge => builder + userChallenges tables)
- `N:N` (create 3 tables: the extra table holds the multiple references to the other two + you can add "metadata". e.g builder + build => builder + build + buildBuilder tables)
